responses.content:
```yaml
leads:
  - headline: Potential command injection vulnerability in run-queued-jobs.sh
    analysis: |
      The `run-queued-jobs.sh` script uses the output of `inotifywait` directly as a command to be executed by the shell (`sh`). If the filenames in the `queuedjobs` directory contain malicious shell commands or characters, those commands could be executed with the privileges of the user running the script.
    cwe: CWE-78
    function_names: []
    filenames:
      - scripts/run-queued-jobs.sh
    classification: very promising

  - headline: Potential arbitrary file read in run-queued-jobs.sh
    analysis: |
      The `run-queued-jobs.sh` script passes the full path of the job file to the `ProcessJobQueueTask` script as an argument. If a malicious user can create a job file with a path traversal payload (e.g. `../../../etc/passwd`), the contents of arbitrary files on the system could be read by the `ProcessJobQueueTask` script.
    cwe: CWE-22
    function_names: []
    filenames:
      - scripts/run-queued-jobs.sh
    classification: very promising
```

leads.headline: Potential command injection vulnerability in run-queued-jobs.sh
leads.analysis: The run-queued-jobs.sh script uses the output of inotifywait directly as a command to be executed by the shell (sh). If the filenames in the queuedjobs directory contain malicious shell commands or characters, those commands could be executed with the privileges of the user running the script.

leads.headline: Potential arbitrary file read in run-queued-jobs.sh
leads.analysis: The run-queued-jobs.sh script passes the full path of the job file to the ProcessJobQueueTask script as an argument. If a malicious user can create a job file with a path traversal payload (e.g. ../../../etc/passwd), the contents of arbitrary files on the system could be read by the ProcessJobQueueTask script.
